model_answer: I can motivate where the magnetic field is strongest. In a solenoid, the magnetic field is strongest at the center, and it decreases as we move away from the center along the axis of the solenoid. This is because the wire inside the solenoid carries current, and the magnetic field it produces is proportional to the current. We can calculate the magnetic field strength at any point in the solenoid by dividing the number of turns by the length of the solenoid. Therefore, option C, which explains the concept of turns per length and its relevance to solenoids, is the most relevant event that led to the formalization of the use of “little n” as a convenient number density for solenoids.
